It is also refreshing to see a nicer place for locals in lower Haight. A big plus was David Kutz personally coming around to the tables and mingling with guests. Seeing chefs/partners with that passion and interest in their diners is welcomed and unseen by other local chefs with elevated egos. That alone will have me coming back.

ylqULmksKDA__qlOIfv0nw.review_text: Sipping drinks with my sis, wondering about side- ways planters in an earthquake.  I had a great dinner with my sister at Maven when I was last in San Francisco. A hipster resto in the Upper Haight, Maven scores that fourth star from me for its ambience and cocktails. The food is good, and if you've eaten at enough New American-style places you won't find anything you haven't seen before.  If you go to Maven, insist on sitting upstairs; I felt like the Dian Fossey of the SF-dot-com world, perched above people joyfully chatting away at farmhouse tables. The plants on the wall are beautiful, and the high shelves filled with curios are fun conversation-starters.  Especially when the conversation turns to "Hey, what if there's an earthquake?"  We had tasty burgers and a good dessert.  The highlight of the evening for me was my dark and stormy: packing a punch and full of ginger.  I'd love to come back for another girls' night with people-watching.

zHGclvkpYOFPoChJNBqreA.review_text: I found Maven to be intimate, excellent and (upstairs) cozy.   The cocktails were well mixed and prompt.   We had the pork tenderloins, oysters, and scallops.   All were beautiful.    A great date spot, especially if they have the fire going as they did that night.

be_VC6SjhIABLvpGqRlMow.review_text: Nice interior but small, and on busy nights I can imagine that there might be a long wait for seats. I came on a very rainy Friday and it was full. We waited a few minutes for a couple seats at one of the long tables on the main floor.   Small plates are pretty good but you'll have to order several if you are looking for a full meal. We had a few things: duck sliders, squid, fennel-burrata, mushroom something, chocolate dessert. They are very nicely presented - they clearly take pride in the presentation. I liked all of the items except the dessert which I found disappointing - the chocolate cake tasted like a brownie I could make at home. Ice cream was a bit sad, and overall I think the cardamon didn't quite mix well for my tastes.   Service is really good though. David introduced himself to us while we were waiting and was really friendly. Our server was also super nice.   Biggest pain is the parking. Ugh - not fun searching for parking. I'm not sure if I would come back right away because I don't live close by and there are so many options in the city. But I like the atmosphere, love the friendliness, and if I were more local, I would come back for sure.

lxOcZ1VZ58nSCFgcunecjw.review_text: We've been wanting to check out Maven since it opened (the living wall sounded cool...not as great in person) and we had a great overall experience here.  We sat at the bar by the kitchen so we were able see the cooks works their magic.  So much had been written about the drinks that we needed to try them out and I got the summer's kiss which was really good and my wife got a good concoction which was non-alcoholic.  For dinner we ordered a bunch of different small plates and everything was really tasty.  We got the Kampachi Sashimi (nice and fresh), Dungeness Crab (love the avocado in there), Heirloom Tomatoes & Burrata (probably my favorite dish as the tomatoes were amazing), Monterey Calamari (ok but I'm not a huge calamari fan) and the Chinatown Duck Sliders which were really good.  My only complaint was that the dishes were a little pricey especially when you add all of those up but otherwise a great spot for a drink and light bites.

Rdesw9ekWdVNbvHfLYjQdQ.review_text: I wanted to like Maven more--I really did!  It was recommended to me by a guy who used to DJ at Noc-Noc, before they outlawed "live music" there.  The ambiance is delightful, the music is kickin' (or at least it was when I went), and if you get the mezzanine seating, you have a great view.  The staff is very friendly and attentive.  There's only one problem with the restaurant:  The food and beverages simply aren't that good.    I brought a date and we started with some interesting cocktails--I ordered the "Hometown Slut", and she ordered the "Swedish Icepick" (okay, I'm kind of making up the names--I didn't memorize the menu).  Both of our reactions were the same: "This drink is...different..."  For the food, we went with recommendations from the waiter.  The duck sliders were superb, as everybody on here has suggested.  The rest of the food ranged from so-so to meh to unpleasant.  Word to the wise: I'd stay away from the charcuterie plate.    If you want to go to a place that looks really cool, I suppose I'd recommend Maven (although you may as well go to Noc-Noc...it looks cooler and has cheaper drinks).  If you want a delicious meal, I'd try someplace else.

-Z1gznAtTuKlArFiM9tLnw.review_text: Get the duck sliders. You'll thank me later. So simple but sooooo good - duck with a pulled pork consistency but delicious flavor. Beautiful atmosphere.

G1U7vl_vRU5-_0S3TPj8Rg.review_text: Met some friends here for drinks and appetizers. The drinks were overpriced, and the pours were small. We got the fried calamari appetizer which came out cold, with 3 tiny little pieces of calamari on it. The only thing I liked about the place were the high, long, communal tables. I would never go back though.

qcFOaYYk7h1nzueb3RJO1A.review_text: I have been there about 4 times, and each experience gets better and better.  The vibe as you enter the place provides a warm and inviting feel as you walk in.  It's especially nice to have a non-dive bar  option within the Lower Haight.  The service is great.  You'll likely run into Dave or Jay, the owner operators, running around and making sure everything from the food, service, and drinks are to your satisfaction.  They have been very open to hearing feedback from customers in order to provide a 5 star experience.    The menu is designed to allow customers to pair food and drinks.  However, you can order whatever combo you like.  I've had the Maven Burger, Fries, Calamari, Artic Char, Cheese Plate, Duck Sliders, and their Chocolate desert.  All were very satisfying, and I would order them again  The drinks were just as delicious, and were paired well with the food recommendation.  Kate, the bartender, is about as sweet as they get!!  The drinks and food came out timely, and the servers I had were very friendly.  Upstairs provides a lounge area where you can chill and relax.  The fireplace adds a really nice touch you don't see very often.  in fact, I can't recall too many fireplaces in the city.  Definitely a spot where you can go with friends or take a date.  But be sure to get there early, and understand you may have to get a drink or 2 while waiting to get seated.  It's been pretty busy every time I've been there.  Lastly, they do close at mid-night......I wished they closed at 2am :(  Good luck to Maven......they have a bright future ahead.

HVjLUH8nY_4bdJJLmBlmJQ.review_text: Signed up for "Urban Daddy's" and Mini Cooper's "MiniNightOut."  After cocktails at the Redwood Room in the Clift, our chauffer drove us in a brand new Mini Cooper S Paceman ALL4, the new Mini SUV but ours was tricked out with filming lights so the backseat was like TaxiCab Confessions with a mini cam focused on us and another one on the hood of the new Mini.  I am a marketing aficionado, love anything to do with marketing and we all know how clever Mini marketing is ... this was really cool. So they pull up in front of Maven and more photos, BBB felt like she was the object of paparazzi which she rather enjoyed and hammed up in entertaining fashion.  We were told to wait till they could clear a place in the upper seating area so we patiently waited awhile and noticed how nicely designed the Maven is.  Great neighborhood bar/small plates place. She had a "The Gold Digger,' (hmmm...) and I had a "5 Spot" I think ... drinks are good, the Chinatown Duck Slider was like Pulled Pork Duck, quite savory but I really liked the heated olives.   A nice crowd, quite slammed on a Friday night but UD and Mini got us good seats, comp cocktails and small plates and life was good ... still is actually. Kudos to Mini Cooper, Urban Daddy and the Maven ... then we headed to THE GRAND - (next review up -)

2tIN9jTDxEoF-gSRSnUkPw.review_text: My 2 friends and I waited only 10 mins or less for a table on a Saturday night!  Omg the Brussel sprouts. So succulent and savory...I am salivating right now just reminiscing that plate.   The fries were okay, nothing out of the ordinary.  Duck sliders were like pulled pork, but it was pulled duck. Savory mushroom in the middle which I feel really pulled the mini burgers together. Ate that like a hungry monster in 3 bites. Slider came with 2 buns but we asked the waiter if we could add another bun for our odd number party and the waitress was kind to do so.   Will be returning next week so that the 3 of us could each get our own plate of Brussel sprouts. Yes folks, they are THAT good.  Romantic ambience with dim lighting. House was packed. Open-ish/peek-a-boo kitchen. Only con I'd say is street parking is horrific and peeps steal your parking spot if you don't butt in so you better pounce on that if you see one!

wnyjsQhQjkBy7LhvCRO8aw.review_text: OK, so the bartenders were awesome. Nothing on the drink menu really grabbed my attention so I asked to have something special made with absinthe and bourbon. The bartender whipped up a concoction with egg whites, maple syrup and lemon and it was just fantastic-- exactly the flavor profile I was looking for. If anyone knows what this drink is called please let me know! :D  The food left little to be desired in my opinion. The menu was very limited and since I was not super hungry, I opted for the duck slides-- which were tasty enough, however there were only two sliders per order.. for $10. I get it, its duck... but still... the fact that it didn't come with chips or fries left the presentation looking very bare and lacking value. Once the sliders came I ordered fries since I didn't think the pieces would be enough. When they arrived they were soggy, unlike the fries my friends ordered. It was no big deal switching them out but the fact that it had to be done was a bit off putting.  Nonetheless, I will probably return to Maven but keep my patronage on a strictly boozy basis.

6u3-ydskxKVASq-Hn1akiA.review_text: I don't usually post reviews so long after I've visited a place, but a friend visiting SF prompted me to add my experience to the rest of the glowing reviews.  In short, the bread pudding french toast was and still is the BEST I've ever had in my life. I very rarely go for sweet brunch, so never before this experience had I ordered french toast in a restaurant and eaten a full half portion. I would have had the whole thing if my boyfriend had let me. This menu item alone makes Maven worth the visit.  The drinks are also quite delicious. Absinthe champagne (Death in the Afternoon) wasn't very absinthe-y in flavor because the champagne overpowered it, but you're still left with the scent which could be ideal for those who are curious but not that into licorice/anise. The Sparkling Paloma is as tasty as you expect. In addition to the bread pudding french toast, my boyfriend and I split the eggs benedict. In my opinion, this was just okay; not my style. The whites were a bit watery, yolk very soft but not at all runny. Collard greens were a little bitter, but the sauce was good and so were the potatoes. In any case the boyfriend loved it, and sitting by the counter with a view into the kitchen we both enjoyed watching the chefs make it. Also think it's worth noting that we were offered ketchup and hot sauce for the eggs, which I appreciated since places like these can sometimes get snooty about it (though maybe that's just in NYC).  Cool interior, too. It's a corner restaurant with huge windows on both street facing sides so you get lots of natural light even on cloudy day. My only complaint was that the service was a bit slow for the fact that it really wasn't crowded when we went.  Also, a warning: the cocktail glasses are indeed as delicate as they appear.

zQHIrX63BN_mEcdMSOJJNQ.review_text: I got to experience Maven as part of a private pre-opening party.  What a great concept!  The small menu has different tastes paired with cocktails or wine/beer.  You are suggested to order your small  "plated" course and then pair it accordingly with a drink from the "distilled" or "fermented" list.  The cocktails are all top-notch.  I am partial to the Santa's Cookies (but I fear it may be seasonal!).  I tried most of the plates and my favorites were the amazing duck sliders & the arctic char.  Nothing is too rich or creamy or covered in weird sauce.  Give it a try!

Ev0pLz-jD7sIZ_YNNev2PQ.review_text: Had I written this review six months ago, it would've been an easy 5 stars.  Now, I'm rounding up to 4 from a 3.5.   After many visits last fall, and a subsequent short move back east, I was excited to return to Maven.  The cocktails are still quite good, though they seem to have lost some of their sparkle.  I ordered two off the B Side menu (Hometown Vixen, and something about stars), and they were both tasty, but nothing memorable.  I then attempted an off-menu request order, which they used to totally crush, which was in the same line- good, but nothing I'd (try to) order again.  My friend, a big whiskey fan, did love the Devil's Halo.   The new food menu looks promising, though our foray into the desserts was unimpressive.  The granita had good flavors, but getting them all together in one cohesive bite was difficult. The sundae wasn't very good, and our table (of girls who love chocolate) didn't want to finish it. However, my fond memories of how excellent their burger is, and how great their burrata and tomato salad was, will keep my review higher than it otherwise might be for the menu.  Maybe it was an off night, given the many excellent experiences I've had here. When this place shines, it *shines*, so I'll be back to give it another shot at the 5 star rating I remember.

HF0YkO5b5JJDxEYTMC_cPw.review_text: Was at Maven last night for its first official opening to the public. For a first night, things seemed to be running pretty smoothly save for some odd arrangements with the host.   We called ahead to make reservations, and were told they don't take any. That's fine and pretty typical of SF. When we arrived, we were told there was no tables for two available, so we asked to put our names down on the list. Then we were told they don't keep a list, but if we wanted to get drinks at Molotov's, we could come back and see if a table was available.   It seemed like the host wanted us out of the bar/waiting area because the restaurant was at capacity, fair enough, but maintain a check-in list so we don't lose our spot for a table while we go over to Molotov's and have our drinks.  Instead we ordered drinks at Maven's bar and were seated within about 15 minutes. Kind of an odd way to start our experience though.  The drinks here are terrific. We had a Hibiki Highball, a Mr. Wiggles (their rift on a Manhattan, and the best drink we tried) and a glass of riesling.   Our waiter was excellent, attentive and had the menu and its ingredients committed to memory.   My biggest gripe with the restaurant was portion to price. I'm not looking for a mountain of food at a high-end restaurant, but asking $9 for two duck sliders (that's $4.50 a slider, people) seems steep. My girlfriend got the steak plate which was $23 for a moderately sized piece of flank steak and some vegetables.   They're essentially offering small plate portions with full entree prices.  I hope they can address that moving forward because the food and drinks are excellent, and it's nice to have some variety in the neighborhood. Best of luck to them.

_lbgVbWTvxV9VTVWU0YnwA.review_text: I thought this place was just OK.  First things first, I went for the wine.  Maybe that was my bad since this place makes specialty cocktails.  Anyway, I ordered the pinot noir and it tasted like a cab (and a bad cab at that).  The glass was barely poured half full (way to save yourself a buck!) and so, I switched it up and went for one of the specialty cocktails - which was not bad - but VERY pricey!  It was the Global Warming....  I only ordered the two drinks because at that point, I knew my bill was already up to $25.00.  I was hungry, so I went for the burger, fries and scallops.  The burger was ALRIGHT... nothing to write home (or rave on Yelp about). It actually had a bit of a different taste to it... one that I'm not a huge fan of - nor can I put my finger on.  The fries were plain, with lots of salt (I like salt, so that's ok).  No interesting dip for my fries, not even a side of Ketchup!  So, finally I flagged my waiter down and got a side.  I needed something to add flavor!  My friend requested the same.  The scallops were probably the best part, but were very thin and really not worth the price - so I wouldn't order them again (I'd rather make it at home myself for half the cost and triple the amount).   I think that this place is trendy and popular at the moment, but the prices are a bit too much for what you get.  Enjoy hipsters, this girl is movin on to better places.

dyHQaGCmxQfwfncnf54pSg.review_text: 5 stars for brunch, 3 for dinner. A bit pricey for trendy and generic small plates, but such is the trend for the new wave of "cocktail" bars. Good service and decor. Nice is you want a fancy drink, but I would not make it a meal destination.

ze0Dw6S7ppOLihN82tmEGQ.review_text: I almost don't want to write this review, because this is hands down my favorite place for cocktails in SF, and I love that I can almost always get a spot at the bar on a weeknight.      The food is dynamite too - don't get me wrong!  I've had the gnocci, and the sliders, and the burger a number of times, and their quality is consistent, and the presentation is dynamite. Everything is fresh and gorgeous and delicious.   What's great is that once in a while, a dish doesn't quite work - rarely, but that, to me, indicates that they are willing to take risks and experiment.  Every time I come here there's something new to try.   The food is excellent, but truly, the cocktails are made so meticulously, and the bartenders are so nice, and it's a mellow, comfortable place to linger, and exactly what I've been missing. The can can has cardemom, cognac and blood orange - it's a dynamic, balanced, strong flavor, exactly on the line between sweet and dry, with a hint of spice.

mlqDCMFoNzQjSOBDeYAtjw.review_text: Maven's burger (flavored with Angustora bitters) is a must-try! We also loved the calamari - with the  tentacles fried and the bodies grilled on the plancha - it was the perfect flavorful combination. Don't kid yourself that you'll get out of there with just one drink on your bill - their creative concoctions beg for a second round. If you're going there on a date, see if you can snag the couch seat upstairs by the fireplace. Also, don't be shy about asking your server to explain the menu items. Our server (Danny? Daniel?) was so knowledgeable especially about the artisan cocktails. We asked him where he learned so much, and he explained that it was all recent training from the passionate owners. That makes me want Maven to thrive!  One area of improvement - I hope they expand/improve their dessert offerings.

2Yreg9gP50LoIPhhLILdYA.review_text: This place is awful. The waiters were complete douche bags - not accommodating AT ALL. And extremely uppity. They had one chardonnay that was steel barreled (WTF??) We're right next to the Russian River Valley for godsakes. The food also left a lot to be desired. I will never go back.

YWRUybg7kKUKP-tdvmZPtA.review_text: Got to give to chef Marik. I stopped in while I was in town on a shoot and he remembered what I ate last time I was in. Even cooked a liilte something off the menu for me. What a place. Will stop by everytime I am in town.

OjzwEyl7DSgjLxUcJeex6w.review_text: 5 stars are reserved for those exceptional places that really wow you and make you say "this was the best ______ I have ever had." Maven is such a place on many dimensions. The melt in your mouth short rib that bursts with flavor stands out in particular -- GET IT if it's on the menu; it's the best short ribs I've ever had.  The Corpse Reviver with gin, lemon, ginger, and coriander is the best drink I have had in recent memory, super refreshing and light but with beautiful complex flavors. The 5 Spot with thai basil and five spice was excellent as well, almost too good for the bland duck sliders it was paired with. Avoid the duck sliders and go for the mussels instead; they are fresh and tender, served with Korean chili pepper and absinthe broth that you will want to soak up with the thick crispy bread.  We also had the brussels (good) and the broccoli tempura (avoid). As an extra treat, sit at the "chef's table" overlooking the kitchen where you can see the busy chefs working their magic. The ambience is great with high ceilings and cool lamps. Can't wait to come back here and try the gnocchi!

iwXJhYapes3l075k2TLwTw.review_text: Went here on a Friday night, loved the atmosphere and decor. Would be a perfect date spot. Two words: duck sliders! The fries were tasty, but a little on the salty side, the warm olives were great, calamari was ok. Bitter Brother in Law cocktail was quite good, but I swear, those dang Chinatown duck sliders stole the show!

BValqLFXLJG8yeGoYfHeCg.review_text: One of the top 5 restaurants I've eaten at. This place is AWESOME!  Came here with a coworker on her suggestion. When given a few options of restaurants, I saw the duck sliders on the menu and decided I had to try them. They turned out to be as amazing as I could imagine. We also had the Kampachi Sashimi, pulled Dungeness crab, seared ahi, and calamari. I can't pick a favorite as they were all quite tasty! The portions were a bit on the small side, which was alright with us as we got to try more food than we normally would have ordered.  Next time, I plan to dive into the bistro steak and the ravioli.

eIa4QJXp5ZNmuFORnuPvDA.review_text: Come at 11am on a Sunday and unlike most brunch spots in SF, there won't be a wait! In fact we ate until about 12 or 12:30 and there was always space. $20 total per person including tax & tip for these 3 items - not bad but not the best deal either. The two of us opted at the bar so we could watch them make food. It was fun looking at the options as they were being made, and the chefs humored us and answered our questions. I also enjoyed the high ceilings and relaxed, low key atmosphere of the place at the brunch hour. MUST-HAVES: I loved the Duck Hash - it was a perfect savory dish (surprising given my usual penchant for sweet options at brunch). DISAPPOINTMENTS: Souffled Pancake - way too dry! * Maven's Souffled Pancake - 2.5 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/mave… (calvados applesauce, cinnamon. $13) Yup, like I said above - overly dry. More like a fluffy dry bread that comes in a cast-iron pan. The apple sauce is pretty good, like the homemade texture (with some chunks) and tasty cinnamon. I can imagine liking this if I completely doused each piece in maple syrup but I didn't want to offend to kitchen asking for it. Completely not what a pancake should taste like. * Duck Hash - 4 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/mave… (fried duck egg, braised sofrito. $14) Wonderful! First, the runny egg yolk. Yum. Makes everything taste better. Second, the roasted potato & onion hash - crisp, tasty. Third, the duck - very tender, very flavorful. Loved this! * Billionaire's Bacon - 3.5 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/mave… (glazed and with pepper. $6) I chuckled when I saw this on the menu because the previous week I'd gone to Sweet Maple and had their Millionaire's Bacon. This is clearly their copy, and it is an inferior one at that. While I like that there's a spicy kick to Maven's Billionaire's Bacon, its texture is also much harder, to the point of being difficult to chew through. The sweet glaze was a little overpowering as well - I didn't get any hint of savory flavor (in the Millionare's Bacon at Sweet Maple that comes through and balances the sweetness really well).

XgHd-PcVg9n30h1Tab6C7w.review_text: Absolutely delicious cocktails (& quite strong too), attentive cocktail waiters, good music and nice atmosphere (especially compared to the rest of Haight Street). I didn't try the food but my friend who has been here several times says it is far less impressive. Amazing drinks -- stick with those...

UyhnjAlyMXtbR-qB5kkhlQ.review_text: Maven is a great place for delicious cocktails as well as small and large plates. I've been happy with the drinks and food here, and I look forward to coming back again.   I shared these plates with friends:  * Kennebec fries with juniper salt + olive aioli - $6 I'm a big fan of Kennebec potatoes. Fries made from them just taste better than other fries. My only complaint is that we didn't get enough aioli.   * Charcuterie plate (smoked prosciutto, rabbit terrine, pate de campagna) - $16 The meats on this platter were all very good, as were the mustard and pickles. As is often the case with charcuterie platters, we had to request more toast.   * Duck, shiitake, bacon sliders - $9 for 2 Our server considerately asked us if we wanted to get an extra slider, since the default portion size is 2 and we came with a party of 3. The duck and shiitake were wonderfully succulent and created a great burger filling.   * Monterey calamari - $9 Generous pieces of calamari and good flavors.   I've liked 3 out of 4 of the cocktails I've had here. The 4th wasn't terrible. That's a pretty high batting average, IMO. (Yes to Let It Bee, Sideways Tilt, Death in the Afternoon. Meh to Chamomile High Club.)   The space is beautifully open and well lit, with a lovely wall garden behind the bar.

9IcUsKuMHHI7aNepnHeyDQ.review_text: If this place wants a star, maybe they will learn to answer their phone.  Purchased a four-course tasting and didn't get to use it. We went on a Monday night and were told there wasn't sufficient time to complete the tasting/pairing menu an hour before closing... OKAY.  But what really pisses me off is that these guys don't even bother to answer their phone for customers.. EVER.. When asked in person, the host replied "Sorry, we are really busy during service hours." When calling almost ALL DAY to try to get through to someone to simply ask a question, no answer.   If you like restaurants that act like they are too good for their patrons, then this pretentious San Francisco spot is for you.  If you are looking to actually get a decent meal and cocktails, I wouldn't step foot in this snooty establishment.  Not often do I get riled up about utter incompetence, but these guys are essentially scamming you out of your money.

h2dXE9UTU48ZK9-mQHeRPA.review_text: Absolutely love this place. The service was awesome, atmosphere was welcoming, and the food was delicious. Tried the burger and fries with aioli sauce- fabulous. Will be back!

E5Q5XrFbKW9n5fcxf4ZjbA.review_text: Fantastic brunch.  I had the johnny cakes and my friend had the Benedict and both were perfect.  My cakes had a cinnamon apple butter and her Benedict was served on top of biscuits with the best roasted sweet potatoes that I have ever had.

CzbO0Ch0EZPzOtKRSt1uCw.review_text: Came here for brunch while wandering in the neighborhood. Great drinks but the brunch was underwhelming. The food was definitely tasty but nothing memorable really

97YdD8tkMkUSvGUw6_u4GQ.review_text: Great food. A bit loud but it was quite pleasant to sit at the cooking counter. My favorites: kanpachi sashimi (goof balance with sweet/sour) and Chinatown duck sliders (tender meats!)  Waiter and service was excellent!

U7ia0lyq8mcvzGWFLOeOtw.review_text: I'd been eyeing Maven for a while now. I finally dropped in on a Friday with a few friends. We sat down right away which was a nice plus for a Friday night. The seating is long-bar type seating where you share a table with other guests. If you have a larger party this may not be the best place but then again I didn't see a lot of large parties so I'm not sure how they accommodate them.   One thing to note: the portions are really small, we all left feeling hungry after ordering 4 dishes amongst 3 people.   As you probably know they pair each dish with a drink. The menu is somewhat small with more small "tapas" plates than larger dishes. Drinks & plates we tried:   Salmon Crudo: Decent, nothing special.  Duck sliders: AWESOME! The waitress was nice enough to give us 3 of them instead of the 2 that comes on the plate so that each of us could have one.  5 spot (drink): Paired with the sliders, really like this! Has a smooth ginger taste. Local Halibut: Good, not great. Just a regular white fish dish w/ a few claims & veggies.  Roasted Suckling Pig: Good, not great. Would have liked for it to be a little more juicy.  Jack of All trades (drink): meh.  Whatever the espresso liquor drink is called: very strong.   All in all we spent $140 on 4 plates & 3 drinks. Not sure id go back again for the price, but it's worth trying at least once.

pI15RINDqpXIk5492xx7PA.review_text: Maven is not exactly what you expect when you think of Haight St; classy interior, well dressed crowds, excellent cuisine abound....definitely a nice date spot too.  There's a good amount of seating but we went on a Friday evening and it was a bit more difficult to get seats during peak hours.   Drinks were solid and the food I'd recommend... -Duck sliders: savory goodness, I think it might come 2 to a order -Chicken: wasn't my choice to order it but ended up really liking it -Fries: always good :)

LdXqkm8tCBcKvdZ4z_2U7Q.review_text: I brought an out-of-town friend here for brunch. We both thought it was OK, but expected a lot more.  First thing first, the bloody mary is just eh. It has a nice spice and some delicious pickled accompaniments, but $11 for a bloody in a collins glass is lame (unless it is the best bloody in SF, which this was not).  Otherwise, the food was ok. I had the duck hash, which was kind of burned and didn't look anything like anyone else's photos, and my friend had the burger, which she said was really good. The longanisa was one of the best I've ever had.  I'll try Maven again for dinner, but maybe not for brunch.

OaRk-RwFEzfOtc45ff0fGA.review_text: Very NOPA-esque, which isn't a bad thing.  The staff was nothing if not patient and attentive, as it took us forever to order (sorry!/thank you!).  I didn't get a chance to try the (deconstructed) savory winter tart that my date ordered, but it looked amazing.  Though I wanted to order the scallop crudo, I didn't want to order anything he wouldn't want to try (made that mistake before), so I ended up getting the braised fennel and watercress, which was flavorful and surprisingly filling (thanks, burrata, olive oil, and the act of eating slowly!).  Though it was tasty, there were a couple smatterings of a mystery sauce on the plate that I wasn't able to identify.  The Chinatown (wtf?) duck sliders were deliciously bold.  I think what would've made the sliders more "Chinatown" was if they put some roasted/crispy duck skin in there with scallions and hoisin sauce.  'Twas a good experience.

ZDbno74-gml5e6wyf22brg.review_text: What a colossal disappointment. I brought my sommelier friend who was visiting. I waited until she was in SF to try it. Service: our server- curt, condescending, slow and not knowledgeable. The other servers who dropped our food (2 others)-pleasant, polite & knowledgeable. The food: UGH! Charcuterie-fine best dish we had. Calamari- all I can say is not good, deconstructed tart (the crust was awful, like a bad bad instant pie crust bad & stale). scallop crudo-apples overpowered the delicate scallop, which would have been good otherwise. Duck sliders - meh. I think we had one other item but it was forgettable. I'm probably even more disappointed because I had amazing food & service at Cotogna yesterday. Will not be back. Was embarrassed about the terrible service & bad food. 2 stars because the space is sexy & the neighborhood needed a joint like this! Hope the kinks get worked out, really wanted to love it.

EzSrmCtkptei9Pl12Fdjiw.review_text: One of the best brunch spots in SF for a few reasons: 1) consistently yummy hangover don't be on a diet type food.  The hash and Cuban sandwich is heavenly. 2)A fine selection of booze.  Nothing makes life worth living like a scoop of absinthe sorbet in a death in the afternoon 3) The most mystifying part of this equation is IT"S NEVER BUSY FOR BRUNCH.  I hypothesize that it's far away from the Castro brunch shit show, but I truly have no idea why it isn't more packed.  NO wait for food while hungover=amazing. 4) around the corner from my house.

mj2wCBzx7RtoL4J2m0xu4Q.review_text: I loved RNM when it was in this space and I had a great time at Maven.  The upstairs is super cozy. Nice fire, comfy couches, mellow, not too crowded. Delicious drinks and the food was quite enjoyable. Tried the duck sliders, agnolotti and artic char. Enjoyed everything. Great place to grab a bite and drinks with friends. Will definitely be going back.

QmGRqMUlI9Aq5CNl0g8OAw.review_text: i love everything about this place, from the stunning decor (wow, that living wall is cool) to the awesome cocktails to the cant-miss menu. I even love sharing tables with strangers in this place, because they tend to make good recommendations on what your next cocktail order should be.   I went with two friends and we basically ordered the entire menu to share. There were things I liked a little better than others--the scallop crudo is near-life-changing--but there were zero flops on that menu. The wait was long, but they were willing to call my cell phone to let me know when our table was ready, and after dinner we all agreed that we'd happily wait to eat that food again. This is definitely being added as not just a neighborhood favorite, but a city favorite.

Hj_GF8MnikDy4BQzf0B8Dg.review_text: It was fairly easy to get seats for 2 on a Sunday evening.  Our server was great but the food was just ok.  We shared the gnocchi, fries, summer squash and burger.  I thought the burger was the best thing - cooked to our request and flavorful.  They have several cocktails along w/ beer and wine options.  Cute neighborhood spot.

kJgvtgPwhH-JDs0IAoGhyw.review_text: Came on a Saturday night for drinks and snacks with the boyfriend.  FOOD: Ordered duck sliders, fries and cheese plate. Everything was ok, but I felt the sliders and fries were definitely on the salty side (especially the sliders). Maybe it's better to start with a few drinks :) Cheese plate was tasty. Everything came out really really fast.  DRINKS: A lot of cocktails. Tried the Hometown Vixen and the Global Warming. Boyfriend had the Devil's Halo and La Coartada. All were very good. But my favorite was the Hometown Vixen.  ENVIRONMENT: Love the look of this place. Dark lighting. Cool geometric red light fixtures. Large wall of plants behind the bar give a weird jungle-y feel. Seating seems pretty communal - big tables, bars, low tables with sofas upstairs. Very laid back.  SERVICE: Really friendly waiter. Seated right away - got to choose either upstairs or at the chef's table. Appropriate amount of checking in and quick with getting more drinks.

HylGr2mRKE9CCC9KvdvCoQ.review_text: My friend and I stopped in for brunch close to 2:00 on a Saturday afternoon after exploring Alamo Square. We were promptly seated at a long communal table with stools. Since there weren't really many people there, it was fine for me, but I can see it being less ideal at peak times.  Their brunch menu is surprisingly limited in terms of food, and I was immediately drawn to the smoked pork benedict. Their Hollandaise sauce was really unique -- I usually find Hollandaise to have a bit of a sharp kick to it, but Maven's version was much lighter, and it went well with the dish. Strangely, I felt like the pork was a little bland, but I've never been one not to like an eggs benedict, so I still enjoyed it.

MGK7RSZhjk0_F8xbi5S-7g.review_text: Very masculine place. Went here for brunch. They don't have traditional bloody marys, so minus one star. They did, however, have Pimms, which I love. Drink came with a metal straw if that gives you any indication of how pretentious this place is. I had eggs benedict and split a side of brown sugar bacon with a friend. Both were delish. Had to sit on a bar stool with no back rest. Not really a comfortable place to sit and drink and also NO parking in this area. I will try other places before returning.

A1mJ0kf_4UhFriEu0KkwNw.review_text: Maven opened around the corner from me just a few months ago and I'm glad I finally made it in to enjoy a few libations and small plates.  The cocktails are creative and strong - I recommend Mr. Wiggles.  The small plates are good, especially the blue cheese, fries (SO GOOD!) with juniper salt, and the duck sliders.  You MUST get the duck sliders.  Pass on the savory tart even if it gets recommended.  Maven is a hip spot for strong drinks after work and offers friendly and patient service.

WKGBFuyUrK5lFVODxPzjcg.review_text: Bring together a great design, $10-12 drinks, and some small bites, and you got me sold. But do I call it a lounge? There ain't no sofas! Do I call it a restaurant? There's more interest in getting your drink on here than in the food. Do I call it a bar? It's too nice and far too much tabled seating for it to be so.  AMBIANCE: Private tables in this two-story location are for wimps. They're also on the second floor separate from the main bar.  Go for the long wooden shared tables with the stools. Nothing says "hello, my pretty" than rubbing elbows with a stranger. Unless you're on the ends, of course. The space is large for the Haight, and the design is more chic than the neighborhood suggests. A vertical grass/herb garden hangs above the downstairs bar, and the stairs going up are cement. Organic meets industrial.  DRINKS: Global Warming was great and smooth. The Nauti-Mermaid was one of the most unique drinks I've had in a while-- coconut and hazelnut. The Beach and Hyde is an excellent early evening drink (as it's caffeinated with coffee) and a whisper of orange. The 5 Spot is kind of forgettable with a roundabout ginger and basil aroma. $10-12 a pop.  FOOD: Duck sliders were incredible. Only complaint: the dish only came with two of them. Not great for sharing if there's more than two people or someone with an appetite. The lemon chiffon cake was unique-- soft cake with a seriously tart rhubarb/strawberry compote on the side, with a small scoop of yuzu ice cream at the other end. $9 and $7, respectively.   SERVICE: Our server was quick and knew the menu. You could see how busy he was, so we didn't expect his attention to be focused on my little duo.   RATING EXPLAINED: Well-curated but not mind-blowing drinks, small portions of good food, and lack of privacy. It's still a great place. Look for the black doors.

TiWF94rl8Q6jqQf2YZSFPA.review_text: Hmmmm.  Where to begin?    Back story:  Came up early SF before a wine event with friends to hopefully catch some yum yums.  Lead up:  Several discussions, searches and walking in and out of places later, we decide on Maven.  The order:  (For a group of 5 mind you).  Smoked Trout Salad.  Wild Mushroom Omelet.  Bechamel Benedict.  Duck Hash.  Maven Banh Mi.  A side of Billionaires Bacon.  Some Sparkling Palomas and Maven Bloody Marys to wash it all down.  Oh, and Bread Pudding French Toast.  The Climax:  Waiting for food and sipping our drinks.  Starving and needing sustenance to absorb all of the wine we are about to consume.  The VERY Happy Ending:  The food here is EXCELLENT!  All of the dishes were to die for.  The smoked trout salad was a great and light way to start with tons of citrus flavors to complement the smokey fish.  The eggs on the omelet were cooked amazingly and the creamy mushrooms were fresh.  The Benedict!!!! was served on the house brioche and damn good.  The Duck Hash droollllll. was nice and tender on top of the chili potatoes and all mixed together with the runny, creamy egg.  The Banh Mi was great with the pickled veggies and fried pork.  The BACON! you can't go wrong.  And my favorite, the Bread Pudding French Toast (I will not explain JUST ORDER!).  And the drinks are allll damn good too.

sOMhmdxxRPbolQ2hmFZJqw.review_text: Though wine and food menu was not as extensive as I would have hoped, knowledgeable staff suggested great parings with the food I ordered (which was delicious), making me more than satisfied with the experience. If you add very cozy interiors (try to grab the couch in front of the fireplace, before someone else does) and a good crowd, you end up having a place where you want to go back.

NCDHIhhi0DoF1uQlmzk6Sg.review_text: [Full disclosure: I know one of the owners.]  Nice, relaxed ambiance... check out the couches upstairs. Lots of innovation here. Each food item paired with both a cocktail and a wine (read it horizontally). Yummy cocktails (we tried Mr Wiggles, 5 spot, Santa's Cookies) and small plates (duck sliders, arctic char, calamari, skirt steak). The arctic char in particular was seared to perfection and comes with a smoked (!) wine broth, and the skirt steak is served with cubes of layered root vegetables fused together (I believe) with maple syrup.  Friendly staff as well.  A welcome addition to Lower Haight. WIsh this place were around when I lived in the area!

0jKUiR_neIQynEKz44pMWg.review_text: This place provides a very cozy and warm ambiance, especially the upstairs seating area. Everything is moderately priced and service is okay, although we always have to  flag them constantly to get what we need instead of them checking up on us. The tapas style duck sliders, fries and the burger were my favorites! They also have a wide array of unusual cocktails but wished had more beer selections.

l3HfLnoT5j9WLHe461MAwA.review_text: Cheese plate, chocolate Napoleon and Pimm's Cup(made just the right way), Yeah!!!  Great after dinner place for drinks and snacks.  Loved the decor and ambiance.  Thank you nice bartender at Noc Noc for recommending to us for cocktails.

3ekCTjKFqSmJzWoA6DK6oQ.review_text: This place wins on all levels. Great drinks, great food, great service, great pacing of courses. We also didn't wait long, and they were super busy. And they sat us in the best seats in the balcony over looking the entire restaurant. Can't wait to go back.

O9iVmgS_hPtNd887LDBctw.review_text: Checked out Maven tonight and I have to say, we were pretty impressed overall.  I remember going to this space when it was RNM back in the day and I am pleased with the transformation into Maven.    You enter into a spacious single open room with several lacquered wooden communal tables to your left and bar seating to your right.  There is also sushi bar-style seating in the back where you can watch the chefs do their thing in the open kitchen.  The stairs on the far right take you to a intimate little loft with modern couch seating to comprise a mini lounge, as well as counter seats overlooking the front room.  This is where we chose to sit and enjoyed the view of the buzzing dinner crowd below.  The menu, while ostensibly limited, offers a nice diverse array of small and large plates, somewhere between gastropub fare and finer dining.  We enjoyed a mix of both types  from the duck sliders to the potato gnocchi.  The sliders were petty good, a bit dry but well balanced with the bok choy and hoisen sauce.  The gnocchi was succulent, melting like butter with each bite.  I also tried the burger, my benchmark dish whenever it is offered.  Served medium rare with muenster, angostura, and house pickles, it was quite good, all the flavors combining for a unique taste.  Overall, the food was consistently great if not perfect.  Service was solid too, friendly and attentive, and made for a wonderful impromptu dinner out.

-qFuoSVFlKgQdZdbFcjDWw.review_text: The drinks are fabulous and the secret drink menu is even better :) The dishes were all fantastic. The burger was extremely flavorful and my fish was cooked to perfection. Will be back!

6zzmdj82ol9oe0G6Qpll1Q.review_text: I think that at $160 for two people, it's a bit of a stretch. Good cocktails, very personable and attentive service, and very happening. I was taken with the fact that you could just walk in without preplanning.  I think some of the dishes were too skimpy for the price, e.g., gnocchi with two or three pieces of asparagus. I wish the calamari dish was all freshly grilled instead of a mix between grilled and fried. Also, the sauce for the french fries could have been more interesting than just tartar (mayo and relish?). Finally, if you're looking for greenery (to eat), you'll need to venture elsewhere.

y6I7waddCQUpHKelJ9sC2g.review_text: I read a Thrillist article on how Maven's Chamomile High Club is one of the top 5 beer cocktails in SF.  It did not disappoint.  The apricot really shown through, and you could actually taste the bourbon and chamomile unlike Sleepy Jean cocktail served at 15 Romolo for brunch.  I also tried the Honor Amongst Thieves and it was also good - the cab reduction was a unique element not seen in most cocktails.  Maven reminds me of Trick Dog in that it serves yummy, well balanced cocktails that are a tad sweet and more "girly."  You still gotta go to one of the B&B bars to get a stiffer drink.

8lPc2Y60XluYmwgOPlJwsg.review_text: We came here for July 4th dinner. The food quality was good, but not impressive. I was disappointed by the # of choices in the menu. I like the duck slider although my friend thought it was too salty. The brisket was basically braised pork. The Korean chili in the mussel made the dish interesting. I don't recommend the salmon, small portion and plain.   The cocktails were not bad. They pair the tapas with their cocktails. Our favorite of the night was the dessert. We had coconut panna cotta. Crunchy top, fresh mango middle layer and creamy bottom with a hint of coconut. I like it because it's not that sweet. I suggest making the bottom creamy layer denser to add some texture.   I wouldn't come back for dinner. But I heard they have a good brunch menu, and would be interested to try.

7_o4DVcADrB9cpST7fDVGQ.review_text: The food was pretty good and our waiter knew a ton about wine. They served it one dish at a time, which was a bit awkward for the 4 of us. I'd try it again in a few months

xBcNPTcCigOS4We-4ZIHqw.review_text: I love classy places like this. The cocktails and food are fancy and exceptional. The presentation of everything is very elegant and that flavors are wonderful. This place is perfect for a nice out with friends if you want to live it up a little bit. Everything on the menu is worth it.   My only complaint is the service. They made the reservation we had very difficult for us, confirming our reservation, but not saving any spots for us. Also once we got there they said all of us had to be there before they even tried to accommodate us. We all eventually had to move furniture by ourselves to sit together, there were about 8 of us, and even then the service was just meh. They could have been more courteous since it was for a birthday and we were also spending a lot of money there. Luckily for them the food and atmosphere was so great that I'll still give them four stars, but they could have 5 if they improve their service by a lot.

xlLg5ujUqIxRI118NUGS7g.review_text: Amazing food. Amazing drinks (second star to the right). Amazing service. Amazing. Great vibe, design and crowd wise too.

Eb3li-aNqRqlYYLd-WOwGA.review_text: Came for Sunday brunch for my first visit. Sat at the bar in front of the kitchen which was cool to watch to cooks at work. I had the duck hash and side of billionares bacon. The hash was a bit salty so was the side of potatoes. The bacon, well that was hands down the best bacon Ive ever eaten. I will go back just for the bacon. The drinks are really good and they pair all of their dishes with their cockails. The service could be better...took 15 minutes to get our drinks.

NtCaWVg6MU1jikn6FKHp4w.review_text: Maven is right around the corner from me, which is always nice to hear. The beers on the menu were quite typo-tastic ("21st Addmendment", "Unibourne", "Hennenpin, Ommengang") but I came for cocktails. Mr Wiggles was an interesting take on a Manhattan, but it was far too sweet for my tastes.  We ordered the Kennebec fries, which came with far too little of the "olive aioli" - there was only the slightest artful smear on the plate - and the Maven burger, which was really quite tasty, but it was extremely salty. Nearly salty enough to send back to the kitchen.  I like the communal sort of feel, the aesthetic is really pleasant, but I think the other reviewers' comments about the price-to-portion ratio are well-founded. I mean, the burger was probably the most bang for the buck, at $11.  Either way, I'll probably be going back - it IS around the corner.

J26rLFEmURqUVADQYYxqBQ.review_text: High sense of service even with lots of questions and the questions get answered with appropriate servings of drinks.

NLlrYDdoZWuK1kK_t49X7w.review_text: My boyfriend and I went to Maven for dinner this evening around 7pm. The restaurant was basically empty - there were maybe 5 people sitting at the bar, and no one at the tables. We had the duck sliders, which were very tasty, followed by the Arctic Char for me, and the burger for him. I was in love with the Char - succulent, moist, and flavorful, with a little bit of skin (crispy, delicious skin!), topped with a bit of chutney, and surrounded by fried brussels sprouts coated in sweet, red verjus, omg! There were white beans, too, but I was totally engrossed in the fish and brussels sprouts.  My boyfriend didn't think the burger was anything special, however. Excellent service from the host & waitstaff.

XCcHznKF6z8asDVzvri7xg.review_text: The food was pretty tasty but a little pricey for the small plates. I wish they were a bit cheaper so I could sample a whole bunch of 'em at once. As it was, I just had the duck sliders which were really good! But not a meal. Go for the cocktails instead, which are all really good, at a typical $10ish a pop.  It's kind of annoying that they don't take reservations, and it can get pretty crowded. It also gets really noisy, so I would go early (like, 'round 6), have a drink, and then get a real meal somewhere else. Or have this place round out the end of the night, and go at like 10-11.  Not good for groups, unless you love waiting.

6WOJhznm0-PHVwZ0YBgH6w.review_text: Maven is rated one of the best places for cocktails in San Francisco. I couldn't agree more. I personally like whiskey based cocktails, and they did such a great job at these. NOTE: Check out B-side Cocktails on the menu.  For food, get the Chinatown duck sliders. The texture reminds me of pulled pork but it's duck - oriental style. We also shared charcuterie plate and fries. Rabbit rilette on the charcuterie plate is so good that I wish they had given us more.      Check it out if you happen to be in the Lower Haight. You won't be disappointed!

7Kfah0iCqd-SubPiJqZWqQ.review_text: I'd like to give this 3 or  more stars but I'm big on service. The food pairing and wine offerings are superb and delicious - standard SF quality. My problem is the service. The waiter was relatively polite. However, I finished my one drink and my friend was still finishing her beer. It was around 7PM. Our server asked us if we wanted anything else. We said no, meaning that moment - not for our entire stay. He promptly brought us our bill giving a GTFO look. The place was only 1/3 full and not busy. We weren't holding space and I find it incredibly rude to drop the bill in such a rush after one drink and one appetizer. I wanted to try the chocolate mousse dessert but was rushed out in such a manner that I didn't feel like asking. I don't know if it was a miscommunication or near end of his shift, but please no more check dropping on a dime.

vRhya8Ig7llSdrvWrSuovw.review_text: Tonight, mum & I went in and had a great time. Excellent service, good food, reasonable prices, perfect ambiance. Maven we will see you soon once again :)

5O3bu2s6T-bc84w6zIQT1Q.review_text: This is a really well balanced restaurant.  I used a Bloomspot for a 4 course chefs tasting for two and was amazed.  Normally these coupons can steer you wrong but this place made all the other wrong places worth it.  I took a friend for her Birthday and we both loved every bite.  She is from italy and still loved the Tortellini dish.  The drinks were amazingly complimentary to the dishes and can't wait to go back for more and try the others.  The red wood communal tables are gorgeous and you can get to know neighbors if you wish.  The staff was very friendly and described each dish with perfection.  The duck sliders were my favorite.  I love the living wall above the bar giving a fresh look balanced with the intimacy of the tables contrasted by the high ceilings for a feeling of space.  I normally don't return to restaurants since there are soooo many to try in the city.  But this will definitely be my go to staple restaurant when friends  want to get together or family visiting from out of town.  A gem of lower Haight.

ZmFl1-MRitlcxU7UAPpCNw.review_text: My boyfriend and I came here last Saturday for our anniversary brunch (I rarely get time to get  a proper brunch due to work, so it's a treat when I do!).  Located in the Lower Haight, parking wasn't too bad for a Saturday and we managed to get parking across the street (2$ an hour). We started off with a few cocktails which were nicely crafted. I had the "Smokin' Maria" which is a riff on the bloody mary, made with tomato water not juice (so don't be expecting a typical bloody mary). It was nice and refreshing, and a nice take on a classic.   We both ordered the eggs Benedict, and were a little disappointed. When they came out, the temperature was just below luke warm. We figured that they probably plated the greens and then waited for the eggs to be done (I'm assuming you also don't want to place a poached egg on hot items). Also, we both agreed that there needed to be some more ham to help balance out the slight bitterness from the greens. Eaten together (greens/egg/ham), everything was able to come into balance, which is what I'm sure the dish was conceptualized to do. Also, anything that said "spicy" next to it, such as the "spicy potatoes" or "spicy  hollandaise" was anything but. Too bad, because that spice would have been great!  We also had the mezcal infused chorizo, which was just chorizo-y (we couldn't really taste the mezcal), and the bacon egg biscuit which seemed to lack bacon (but also still quite tasty).  We will probably be back, but with the range of brunch places to try, it may take me a while to get back around.

9IF2ZMnkrZlvxCHcO0h1EQ.review_text: Great atmosphere, unlikely setting for lower Haight. The idea of pairing cocktails with food is the theme of the menu.   The global warming cocktail is not to be missed. Easy to sip and with an absinthe sorbet float, it's an unusual treat.

Faa1zHzyVDN_dhCuWTWb6A.review_text: This place nailed it! The food is delish, the wine list is awesome and the staff is great.  We've never had to wait for a table, even on NYE!  LOVE!

Sg_BvnTHsbc1AABiJjaiPA.review_text: I love the cozy upstairs lounge! And with the fireplace. :)  Their cocktails are yummy. The cauliflower soup, fries, and brussels sprouts were good. The gnocchi was like a dish made with leftover from the other dishes, and the gnocchi itself was mushy -- like balls of mashed potatoes. The duck sliders were too sweet and dry at the same time, no bueno.

p08F3g2_lSSdzyjnVcvt4w.review_text: Come here only for drinks!  I came here with a Bloomspot. $50 for $100.  Let me tell you it was not worth $100.  It's close to being worth $50.  The drinks were not bad except the portions are kids size.  Also I'm not sure how they selected the drinks for pairing with each entree.  They didn't really match up.  The seared halibut was overcooked.  The tortellini was nice but could definitely be better.  The chocolate dessert was okay too.  And the other dish, well...  I forgot what I ate so you know what that means.

pLbI4bRm1egAp1u9pw2Ubg.review_text: A girlfriend and I came here on Tuesday night for dinner and a drink. I started with the pumpkin spice deliciousness cocktail, which was e perfect blend of brandy and sweetness, with the fall flavor I was looking for! We shared the burger which was good, though I wouldn't write home about it. The Brussels sprout deserve a letter home! Overall it's a fun spot I would certainly recommend, though not sure I'll be back. The menu is smaller and pricier than I would like to see.

bQCHF5rn5lMI9c5kEwCaNA.review_text: The real selling point to Maven is the gorgeous, intimate interior, in stark contrast to the somewhat gritty, if gentrified, Haight Street just outside. There's a soaring wall with lush plant life splashing out, providing a colorful, dramatic backdrop to the bar. The rest of the ground floor has several large communal tables that can accommodate groups both large and small. There's also a sexy, darker, more private loft space which has several places at a counter overlooking the entire restaurant, as well as sofas and lounge chairs.   Maven is definitely a great lounge for dates or drinks with close friends, and it's got some pretty good cocktails. As for the food, I've tried the same tasting menu that others have mentioned here. The only memorable part was the Chinatown duck sliders, the Asian aspect coming from oyster (?) sauce, shiitake mushrooms, and "Chinese greens." From the regular menu, these sliders are probably your best bet for value, size, and quality.   Overall, Maven adds a trendy vibe to the neighborhood and I certainly wouldn't mind coming here again for their drinks, smaller menu items, and intimate vibe helped by courteous, unobtrusive service. While the food would probably merit 3 stars on its own, this place as a whole gets bumped up to 4 stars for the ambience.

Uo1YROma_IEgvx-wKTu_oA.review_text: Update - A few hours after posting my initial review of the incident I had at Maven, someone from the restaurant called and apologized and stated that they acknowledged there was a "comedy of errors" on their part leading to the double and extra charging, and that they were issuing a refund to my credit card.  I'm updating my review to reflect that they did eventually make the situation right, which I appreciate, but I still think that it sucks when the only way to get a business's attention on an issue is to call them out publicly.  Whether true or not, it gives the impression that they only care about their PR, not your experience or what they did.   Overall, I think Maven is about average is for San Francisco these days: solid food and drinks but nothing ground-breaking, a little too expensive for what it is, and the overall feeling that it's trying too hard to be hip and trendy.  Just like in many other of these types of places popping up around the city right now, it feels like customer service can easily be subtracted out of the equation.

2SBxCX9cDzrLVdSweCQrXQ.review_text: Mmm the cocktails here are delicious. I tried several but my favorite by far was the Fireside. It tasted very warm and seasonal!!   Wait staff is superb, too. When I leaned in while my friend was asking for drink recommendations, our waitress suggested I sit tight because she has different recommendations for each person!! How nice.   I also tried the rainbow trout. Deliciously tender! The skin is incredibly crispy. There was also supposed to be "leek dumplings" but in the dark (& in part to my drunken stupor) I think they tasted more like cream cheese wontons than anything else. (Still yum!!)   5/5 will come to eat&drink&peruse the restroom again.

PBeuCjN4dBut_iqeRXYBgw.review_text: The cocktails here are absolutely delicious and interesting.... they are paired with food which is, unfortunately, something else they serve here.

_iobGls750wUaWmIlXkR7A.review_text: Not impressed with the food.  Mussels were super small and boring, nothing else impressed me on menu.   Go 4 cocktails only , cool atmosphere for that.

QGhHUuUFNp7zLZ4DvrNqYw.review_text: I loved this restaurant! I had the duck sliders, my friends had the mussels and the gnocchi. The food was absolutely delicious. The cocktails were also amazing. Would definitely come back, recommended!

cCPjASKs5YpMB4BmN2oSZg.review_text: Maven feels like more of a cocktail bar than a restaurant - though a really good one. The food menu's purpose is to drive alcohol sales; it's good, but isn't large enough stand on is own. Because I prefer eating too much over drinking too much, but certainly am no stranger to either, Maven's menu concerned me a bit until we arrived at the restaurant.  With that said, everything we ordered was worth eating, with some dishes being great. The duck sliders in particular were excellent: moist, even juicy, slightly tangy, and filling for a slider. The butternut squash pasta was aided by thinly sliced Brussels sprouts and other veggies. It didn't look like much but was more satisfying than expected. The Kumamoto oysters were good, like they always are.   I'd suggested Maven to a former girlfriend who'd known the space as RNM. We're just friends, and happily so, but sometimes...well, you just never know.   So when we lucked into two seats at the bar and started running down the Distilled menu, the conversation started getting a little interesting. By that I mean that the drinks aren't cheap, but they're worth it. Sitting across from a bartender making interesting drinks for a couple hours definitely made us drink more quickly.   Wait, um, did I just mix in a few double entendres or am I overthinking this?  Anyway, my one objection to Maven isn't pricing - I got over that when looking at the menu online. It's that people waiting for tables are asked, and somewhat herded, into a small corner area between the bar and the front door, to "keep this area clear for people eating at the bar." Um, you mean, like me? Fine, it's crowded, no worries. But at least keep the front door when it's cold and windy - please don't prop it open! The big draft was killing the mood for...my friend.

XmEywucVDyUP9VJ4SXGjzw.review_text: A revisit to Maven.  And of course the duck sliders were wonderful.  Great food for a great price.  But my other food courses were a bit of a letdown.    For example cauliflower soup.  The soup came with crisp rye bread, lemon, persillade and raisins.  All of that was interesting. A lot of interesting.  But the soup itself was thin and pretty much without any taste of cauliflower.  The headliner of the plate never showed up.  Rainbow trout was perfectly prepared and was accompanied by roasted sunchokes and a parmesan broth.  So far so good.  But something in the plate was acid.  Too acid.  Much too astringent, at least for me.    Of course my Devil's Halo cocktail was great but the meal overall was just so so.

anSJThb6sQByQS9sPIC3bg.review_text: Word of the Meal: NONCHALANT  I've only been living in the SF Bay Area for less than a year (approximately 8 months or so now), but I am quick to jump on a new brunch option as the next San Franciscan. Submerged in such a thick cultural milieu where brunch can range the gamut from classy to trashy has definitely piqued my curiosity. The search for the next Nopa or Mama's has definitely become a fun way to explore the city and spend quality time with the Mister and friends. After hearing from a DailyCandy email about Maven starting a new brunch concept, I had anticipated a crazy wait time on opening weekend. After avoiding the first two weekends or so, the Mister and I stopped in today at about 1pm and to our surprise were seated quickly. Actually, not only was there not a line, but we could also pick out our own spot amongst the communal tables - a huge plus especially when you're picky about who to avoid sitting next to (e.g. no babies, no loud, obnoxious fraternity guys or sorority girls, etc.). Immediately upon entering, we were greeted warmly by someone with a chef's coat. He didn't introduce himself, but if he did and was the chef, that would have been a sweet touch.  We sat by the window at the end of an empty communal table. The day started out overcast and by the time we left (about 3:40pm) it was hot almost too hot to sit by the window. We started out with ordering some drinks - the Summer's Kiss (a refreshing strawberry, tomato water concoction with gin or vodka I think with a metal straw, a cool detail), the Death in the Afternoon (champagne poured over absinthe sorbet which was a great presentation and had a mild, not overpowering black liquorice taste), and two Smokin' Marias (which we thought were derivations of the Bloody Mary, but to our surprise were orange and had a different take on heat; instead of pepper and Tabasco, the heat was more like a habanero chilli). All the drinks were yummy, but we would definitely go for seconds with the first two. If you're ready for the habanero kick, by all means, the Smokin' Maria is for you!  To eat, we shared the bacon and cheddar scone which was flakey and more like a delicious biscuit. It actually had visible pieces of bacon which was a nice touch to add texture to taste. I had the southern style eggs benedict which was your standard eggs benedict with smoky ham and some cayenne pepper. The eggs had some runny whites, but that didn't get in the way of me eating it and it was served over English muffin halves. The dish also came with a side of garlic smashed potatoes. They weren't exactly smashed but if they were, I think the seasoning would have been more consistent throughout the side. The Mister had Maven burger cooked medium rare. The cook on the burger was right, and it was served with what tasted like vinegar potato chips. The chips were tangy, light and crispy. I wish there was the option of fries, but alas c'est la vie.   Later in the meal, a friend joined us and we shared a large french press of blue bottle coffee sweetened with chilled agave nectar which was a nice end to a meal. At no time did we feel rushed or pressured to turn over our seats. It was a nonchalant brunch with great conversation and a nice tone to the meal. The living wall over the bar was nice eye candy. The drinks were enjoyable and the menu had a lot of sides (such as billionaire's bacon) which we will definitely try in the future.   Maven's brunch is definitely an up and comer. Located in the Haight, I hope that the tourists stay away and the feel of the brunch remains nonchalant. Although, I enjoy the like of Mama's and Dottie's, brunch places with hype and long lines, I find my most enjoyable meals over conversation and light-hearted exchanges in nonchalant spots like Maven.

h_UEAeBeBuSbeayDaPXk-g.review_text: This place is the bomb-diggity!!!! Great craft cocktails/beers/wine....paired up with small bites and entrees....AWESOME concept!!!! Sit upstairs next to the fireplace!!!!

ygGGbMOTPsm98Y8KCOWT_w.review_text: Awesome place to eat and drink... Maven burger and the nauti mermaid were great!

yReuES_ilc025J_GNM-IPA.review_text: Sent this to a friend:  "And have you been to Maven??!  Wow.  Just had a light, but expensive meal there, that was, absolutely, worth every penny.  It was fucking amazing.  Best service I think I've ever had... and every bite was bursting w/ flavor, just begging for attention, but in a not-annoying way."

hCifJh25zXGVZv9KacaKIw.review_text: The boy and I had just finished an afternoon of hiking up in Sausalito and we decided that we needed snacks and drinks to revitalize us.  I begged him to take me to Maven which has been on my list ever since they opened a month ago.  And snacks and drinks we had! (and had...and had...)  The concept here is fantastic--we've all had wine pairings and beer pairings before--but what about COCKTAIL pairings with food?  Mmmm.  And I love how the menu doesn't hit you over the head with the pairing suggestions--it just sort of pairs horizontally across the menu so you can feel free to try their pairings or you can pick and choose given your liquor preferences.  We sat at the bar, which boasts a great assortment of hand-picked liquors.  We were especially impressed that they carried St. George's gin!  I had been wanting to try it ever since I read about them on TastingTable.  I can't say enough good things about the food.  There *would* have been pictures of all this yumminess had I not inhaled everything as soon as it was set in front of us.  We started off with little nibbles: Global Warming and Three Little Birds and a plate of fries with aoli.  Then we moved on to the scallop crudo which was a bright and refreshing counterpart to the hot salty crispy fries we had just snacked on.  I could have licked the plate and made sure I didn't miss a single morsel of the tart apples on the plate.  I was sold.  Light snacking?  Forget it.  I needed to try more.    We followed that up with the Chinatown duck sliders which were sauced to perfection.  I cannot recommend enough that you get a glass of the La Maudite to pair with it.  The slightly sweet amber red ale is an amazing counterbalance to the mildly spicy sliders.  Divine.    Even though we had dinner waiting for us at home, we couldn't resist trying just a little more of the menu--so we chucked our best intentions of going home and having salads for dinner and stayed where we were.  On the owner's recommendation, we tried the Artic Char.  I think I just drooled on my  keyboard thinking back on it.  The crispy skin, the tangy broth, the pickled mussels, the PERFECTLY cooked fish...  It was a work of art.  I am talking, straight up, party in my mouth.  We paired that with the Hibiki Highball (which comes with a block of ice in the glass--I have a weakness for highball glass sized ice blocks or ice spheres).    We wrapped up the night with the Mayan chocolate brownies with the house-made cardamom ice cream and the New Boy Valentine.    The space is beautiful!  It's perfect for a cozy date, or a place to grab drinks and snacks with girlfriends.  It's modern and trendy without being crazy or overly pretentious.  The place was packed by 7pm on Sunday, which is impressive for a month-old restaurant.  I'm glad we stopped by early for our snacks and drinks since it looked like there was a wait by the time we got up to leave!!    We'll be back soon for sure!!

gDycHZPdRGIvKlWCAgsexw.review_text: We had -duck shiitake sliders -- good: but would have preferred without shiitake -raw zucchini & halibut salad -- uninspired/bad: weird sauce, not enough salt, n -trout with pea puree: delicious -green salad with crispy quinoa: delicious -some thyme and bourbon/scotch cocktail: good, not amazing -champagne  more hits than misses but seemed pricy for the food:deliciousness ratio

JGnqasIkGMLfSejt7mw9qQ.review_text: Went to Maven twice in one week AND I had to cross a bridge to get here! I feel slightly conflicted with my review. On my first visit, I was completely blown away by the tasty small bites and clever drinks. However, my second visit was not as spectacular as my first. So I will settle with 4 stars for Maven.  Let me start off by saying this: all of the rage you hear about the Brussels sprouts are absolutely true. Maven brilliantly reinvents these usually despised and frowned upon mini cabbages. They are so delicious...and nutritious! Roasted in apple gastrique, the shells are crisp and smoky while the interior is nutty and tender. The caramelized sugar brightens the flavor and creates a mild tartness. But proceed with caution; the savory tartness might be a bit too much (AKA eat in moderation because they can overwhelm your taste buds and the sprouts start to lose their magic).   Now onto the Chinatown Duck Sliders! During our first visit, these were out of this world good. Succulent pieces of pulled duck topped with a fat juicy black mushroom and fresh gai lan, all nestled between two lightly toasted buns. Oh my Atlanta! My friends and I were left speechless. Simply a lot of head nodding. Yet, on our second visit, the flavors were more subtle and didn't blend as well as the first time. It was still good but the duck was dry and I barely tasted the gai lan.  We also tried their Kennebec Fries and Monterey Calamari. The fries are your standard fried potatoes--I actually prefer Mickey D's fries more. The calamari came with an addicting Thai chili. It was not cool how half of the squid was fried (arms) and the other half wasn't (body). That's not calamari if the squid isn't fried!  The drinks are consistently solid. My friend loves the Nauti' Mermaid and I recommend the 5 Spot. You receive plenty of booze and an abundance of spellbinding flavors in one glass. Maven has hipster written all over it, frequented by young and attractive ladies and gents. There is always a wait but it's never as long as the hosts estimate. The decor and atmosphere are modern and trendy with a tinge of intimacy. You sit at long wooden communal tables, but nothing wrong with getting cozy with your fellow diners. Service is exceptional. The waiters kept refilling our water. It's SF, so expect to wander and battle for parking. My friends and I speculate that Saturdays are the best nights. Our first visit was a Saturday and the food was outstanding. Will definitely return for the Brussels sprouts and duck sliders!

JOjZ6khsnR4CKI4w246Izw.review_text: A few days after my first review, I received a message from the owner apologizing for our experience and let me know that they had a hostess and had implemented a wait list.    So, we went back and my 1 star review is now a 4 star review.  Upon our arrival, the hostess greeted us and we were immediately seated at the chef's counter, which is wildly entertaining.  The service was friendly and prompt, and our server was helpful in my choosing between 2 cocktails.  I got the 5 Spot, which is absolutely delicious as was the butternut squash agnolotti.  The person I was with thoroughly enjoyed the Mr. Wiggles and the hanger steak.  The food and drinks were so good that we also got the Mayan Chocolate for dessert, and I would go back just for that.    Our experience was great, and we can't wait to go back.

I-0Be1dHEacp293TeRUDpw.review_text: This review is for Boy Wonder/Boner Fruit.. you know who you are. ;)  We had an awesome meal here. Everything from the food to the drinks, the service, and the atmosphere were awesome.   The three of us sat at the bar (in front of the chefs) and watched them cook and dish up plate after the plate.   From what I recall, after a few drinks, our bill was an incredibe deal, everything was fantastic, and we had an outstanding time. I'm stoaked about our impromptu dinner. :)  I look forward to being back. I'll have to check out the upstairs as that seems to be the talk of the town.   Run to Maven!

UzGeH8ZeDG4SM3In6HYHjw.review_text: Great spot for a burger-and-a-cocktail date night. They have delicious burgers to which they innovatively add angostura bitters for a bit of extra meatiness. The cocktails are creative but can be a bit hit-or-miss -- definitely ask your server for recommendations if you're not a fan of candy-sweet drinks.

Lzr1Vzbw6gMMKEiPSggxjg.review_text: I can sum up this place only one way...entirely forgettable.  And not because I had a few Plinys at Toronado...I'll stick to Rosamunde or Squat and Gobble next time.

HnJTVSEVjj08XdY2sOBKDQ.review_text: Not impressed - cool space, dishes and drinks sound good on the menu but aren't well executed.  Food was ok, not terrible but for the price, it's not worth it.

XBiQVWlPhrhLh-rRLCZhyg.review_text: Definitely a fun-hipster attitude. Fun cocktails (I just loved some good ol' Global Warming), and decent food. However, if you are looking to get full, I suggest you eat somewhere else first because most of t he food portions are somewhat miniscule.   Bartender was friendly, answered all our questions about the fancy drinks he was making. Service was pleasant. Great atmosphere, wide selection, come enjoy!

jaEDhTO1Xy6qzxdruF25Tg.review_text: I really like the idea of this place. While I visited the bay last, I learned why you'd pair some wine with some cheese. I gained an appreciation. Here at Maven, I got a similar experience. Food is paired with beer and wine. Each item had a counterpart in the liquids department. This is a great way to get drunk if you order a drink with everything you eat, but most likely you'll be broke before doing so.  For a gastropub-type of place, prices are where you'd expect so I won't get into it because I don't think it's the problem. I think portions are. We were frustrated with the fact that the item we loved most (the brussel sprouts) was served in the tiniest portion ever. Even the calamari (also delicious) served more people. This is annoying.  On that note, I do recommend the brussel sprouts. They were the crowd favorite. Closely followed by the calamari. Various chunks and slices of calamari fried up lightly. Still tender and delicious. The duck sliders were a bit underwhelming, mainly because they were served cold. Considering they each took a couple bites and there were just two of them, we wished there was more for what we paid. Finally, the burger. It's a burger.  Drinks were spot on. I think this is their forte. Service was a little bi-polar with one overly excited server who was very amusing, and one extremely not so amused and bored. Atmosphere was great, with long tables and a lot of good energy floating around. Worth coming back to for the drinks and a good conversation.

MLPGlFG75NNe4ufCC5_Caw.review_text: The food was fine, but not amazing for the price.

YFZLBlnojAFjdii1ufdNXA.review_text: finally got to try this place on a tuesday night when the place wasn't packed to the gills.  the cocktails definitely lived up to their reputation.  I ordered two and thought they were both spectacular; perfect balance between alcohol and mixer.  foodwise this place was also a winner.  the duck sliders in particular were amazing.  the shredded duck was cooked just right and had a great savory taste.  the little poppy seed buns also held up really well.  the potato gnocchi with english peas was also delicious.  i was a bit disappointed with the mussels... the broth tasted good, but the mussels didn't taste like they had soaked up much of the broth.  But overall, the experience was a good one.  I wish they had larger plates, however.  After splitting five dishes among 4 people, I was still hungry.  So we ended up going to Uva to get a pizza afterwards.

2EtTrxsc7iDohHcSU2sAUw.review_text: I'm not one for long reviews, so, let me say: GO TO MAVEN. The food is carefully prepared and it shows. The drinks are %^*(&$^% amazing and equally cared for. Just take a food snob's advice and get a table.
